trial_identification.studytitle: Efficacy of Clinical Pilates versus general exercise for chronic low back pain: a randomised controlled trial.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect on low back function of Clinical Pilates versus general exercise in adults with chronic low back pain
trial_identification.secondaryid: Effect on chronic low back pain and function of Clinical Pilates

interventions.interventions: People with chronic low back pain will be screened via telephone and undergo a physical screening. Baseline testing will be performed at The University of Melbourne and the participant randomised into one of two groups (i) Clinical Pilates (ii) General Exercise. the intervention will last for 6 weeks after which all participants will be reassessed by the same blinded assessor. Both interventions will comprise 12X1 hour visits for supervised exercise over 6 weeks (2 per week) to the trial clinic plus home exercises daily. The supervised sessions will be conducted by a physiotherapist in small group format with up to four participants. An exercise diary will be kept and monitored by the supervising physiotherapist. The Clinical Pilates programs are tailor-made Pilates exercises based on a history and physical assessment. The exercises are chosen according to findings on assessment and are performed on pilates equipment, with home exercises prescribed as an adjunct to the equipment-based exercises.
interventions.comparator: The general exercise program is a standardised set of exercises including exercise bike, abdominal, back and limb strengthening using weights, exercise ball and theraband tubing.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 6 weeks following randomisation, with follow up at 3 months and 6 months following completion of (6 week) program

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Low Back pain with a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 6 weeks following randomisation, with follow up at 3 months and 6 months following completion of (6 week) program

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Function with a Patient Specific Functional Scale (PSFS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 6 weeks following randomisation, with follow up at 3 months and 6 months following completion of (6 week) program

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of Life with a 36-Item Short-Form Health Survey (SF 36)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 6 weeks following randomisation, with follow up at 3 months and 6 months following completion of (6 week) program

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Self Efficacy with a Pain Self Efficacy Questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline and 6 weeks following randomisation, with follow up at 3 months and 6 months following completion of (6 week) program

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Saggital Spinal Posture and Range of Motion with a Digital Dual Inclinometer

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Low back pain with or without leg pain on most days for the last three months, pain greater than 4/10,
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Back Surgery, Spinal Infection, Fractures , Osteoporosis, Hip Osteoarthritis, Ankylosing Spondylitis, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Low back pain of non-musculoskeletal origin, Workcover, Transport Accident Commission or legal claim, Pregnancy, Acute disc prolapse, treatment involving exercise in the last six months

trial_design.concealment: After screening procedures, eligible volunteers allocated to a group at random. Sealed opaque envelopes kept in central location and opened after baseline testing by administrator
trial_design.sequence: Block randomisation , computer generated random number list. Variable block sizes will be used , stratified for age.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Centre for Health Exercise and Sports Medicine, Melbourne Physiotherapy School, The University of Melbourne 200 Berkeley Street Carlton VIC 3053

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Centre for Health Exercise and Sports Medicine, Melbourne Physiotherapy School, The University of Melbourne 200 Berkeley Street Carlton VIC 3053

othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: Centre for Health Exercise and Sports Medicine, Melbourne Physiotherapy School, The University of Melbourne 200 Berkeley Street Carlton VIC 3053

ethicsAndSummary.summary: In people with chronic low back pain, a randomised controlled trial comparing the effect of a six week clinical pilates program with a general exercise program on back function with a 3 and 6 month follow up.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: The University of Melbourne Human Research Ethics Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: Melbourne Research Office The University of Melbourne Level 5, Alan Gilbert Building VIC 3010
